utterances.speaker: DANA PERINO, FOX NEWS HOST
utterances.sentences: Hello, everyone. I'm Dana Perino along with Judge Jeanine Pirro, Geraldo Rivera, Jesse Watters, and Greg Gutfeld.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: It's five o'clock in New York City, and this is THE FIVE.

utterances.speaker: VIVEK MURTHY, U.S SURGEON GENERAL
utterances.sentences: I'm deeply concerned as a parent, and as a doctor, that the obstacles of this generation of young people face are unprecedented and uniquely hard to navigate. And the impact that's having on their mental health is devastating.

utterances.speaker: ROCHELLE WALENSKY, DIRECTOR, CENTERS FOR DISEASE CONTROL
utterances.sentences: We've always said that these decisions are going to have to be made at the local level, and that policies at the local level will look at local cases. At this time we continue to recommend masking in areas of high and substantial transmission. That's much of the country right now in public indoor things.

utterances.speaker: JEN PSAKI, WHITE HOUSE PRESS SECRETARY
utterances.sentences: People are tired of masks. I would say not even if you look at the polling, though. There's also a huge chunk of people who still want masks. When you are in a high transmission area which is everywhere in the country, you should wear a mask in indoor settings, including schools. There are states who have rolled back their mask guidelines, that have given more flexibility to communities. They're different. It's not uniform whatever state has done. And certainly, we continue to advise and recommend abiding by public health guidelines.

utterances.speaker: JESSE WATTERS, FOX NEWS HOST
utterances.sentences: Dana, I've never been this confused about what's going on. I had to write this all down because even I couldn't remember it. So, Democrat governors have full statewide mask mandates, and other Democrat governors just have mandates in schools, and other Democrat governors are lifting mask mandates in schools. And the White House agrees with all of that, but if a Republican governor does not, then that they don't agree with. All right. So, we have that. Now this is where it gets really complicated. So, what specifically does the White House support? Well, the White House says they are listening to the CDC. Well, what does the CDC say? The CDC says they still support masks, yet masks hurt children. And then they ask well, who should the American people listen to, the CDC or the governors? And the CDC says listen to the governors. OK? It gets better. And then you ask the White House well, White House, what if the governor says no mask but the CDC recommends mask, what should the people do? And the White House says listen to the CDC and also listen to the governor. They can't understand what they are doing themselves. They say they are following the science and the science is changing so the Democrats are changing with the science, but Republicans didn't follow the science but got to the science before the Democrats?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: So, it looks like the Republicans were right the whole time.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: I can see why you are confused.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Yes. It's very complicated.

utterances.speaker: JEANINE PIRRO, FOX NEWS HOST
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: I want to ask Greg about this. Because Sean Patrick Maloney is a Democrat in charge of trying to reelect House Democrats. And he basically had this tweet here. Democrats' plan to fight COVID is working. Cases are down and vaccines are widely available. Now it's time to give people their lives back. With science as our guide, we are ready to start getting back to normal.

utterances.speaker: GREG GUTFELD, FOX NEWS CO-HOST
utterances.sentences: You know, I said this yesterday that they're trying to look like they are leading the parade rather than chasing it. Because it's the people that are chase -- when he says we're going to - - it's time to give people back their lives, no. The people actually are taking it back.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: You can't give it to them. I mean, this is a bona fide public moment where the American public knew that the government wasn't going to give up -- give up anything because they're too scared. So, the public had to exert their will, and it's all over the world. Now you are seeing it in every country. And it's amazing. This is true democracy. People are voting with their feet and with their faces, because they knew that -- they saw how the government work. The Democrats always love to ask in any kind of issue what about the children? What about the children? When it's climate change, what about the children? Nutrition, what about the children. But not here. And the reason is it's guilt by association. Who's with the children? The rubes, the domestic terrorists, the white supremacists, the other people. Right? So, you can't be on the same side as them even if they are correct. So, this is what happens when you smear entire groups, with like one bad apple you see a confederate flag, you go, they're all racist. So, right now, they are being stubborn, they would rather just look like idiots and be triple vaxxed, you know, double masked, wear a plastic face guard -- which I call the Pelosi, rather than just actually live a free life the way everyone else is.

utterances.speaker: GERALDO RIVERA, FOX NEWS CORRESPONDENT-AT-LARGE
utterances.sentences: I like it.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: However, I want to make a point. It's absolutely necessary and helpful to change your mind based on data. Right? There's nothing wrong with that, there's nothing wrong with being late, but you should think of the possibility for that before you mock the dude who got there before you. When you make --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: When you call them Neanderthals.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes. When you call them Neanderthals or just idiots or whatever, and then you change your mind. If you think there's a possibility, you're going to change your mind, maybe hold off on mocking the guy who was brave enough to go first, because he was. He was brave enough to go enough and you're all now following him.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: And you know what else the Democrats are following, Geraldo? It's the changing political signs. They got information that said that the American people were way passed it, that they understood what Omicron -- it was not as deadly, but that it's better to be vaccinated, so you don't go to the hospital. Now cases are dropping and people are moving on and all of a sudden, the Democrats are like, yes, me too.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: Well, I think that Greg, for all his eloquence, which way too political a spin on it. I understand the politics, but your point, Dana, is the working point, that's the active point. Omicron killed COVID. Everybody got COVID.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: Everybody who was vaccinated, it was like this, is that all there is?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: And then now, suddenly, with people with the herd immunity spreading, and everybody now having tasted the poison and lived. Now, they want out. Everybody wanted out from the get-go.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: They had to be forced, Geraldo. That's not a political point. That's a real point. The government had to be forced to do this, or else they'd still be clinging to this like some of the -- the White House is still clinging.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: But I think why make that political? Why not say Omicron --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I'm not making it political. I'm telling you what I think.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: Omicron happened. Omicron changed the field?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: Omicron changed the whole reality.

utterances.speaker: PIRRO
utterances.sentences: Well then why is the CDC saying you still need to wear a mask if Omicron --

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: Because everybody is trying to spin --

utterances.speaker: PIRRO
utterances.sentences: No, because it is political, Geraldo. It is absolutely political. When Youngkin was elected, it was ground zero for parents and children. Everyone said this guy is the villain. So, when New Jersey Governor Murphy says no masks for kids, he is a hero, but Youngkin was a villain. OK? This is the left recognizing that this is an election year. It's 2022. They are going to lose like crazy in November. John Hopkins came out and they said look, the closures, the lockdowns, the masks made virtually no difference in our society. So, let's get this over with. And when the CDC comes out and they said, well, Rochelle Walensky says, quote, "we've always said the decision should be made at the local level."

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: She does.

utterances.speaker: PIRRO
utterances.sentences: This woman doesn't have the backbone to say what she thinks!

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: It's about Omicron --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Can I ask you something, judge? Given that the surgeon general testified today about the very dangers for children and mental health, would parents have some sort of a collective action --

utterances.speaker: PIRRO
utterances.sentences: No.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: -- against them for not taking the masks off?

utterances.speaker: PIRRO
utterances.sentences: No, the only collective action they have is at the voting booth. You know, the damage, --

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: I agree.

utterances.speaker: PIRRO
utterances.sentences: -- and I have said this before, history will not look kindly upon us for what we have done to our children. For these teachers to not be masked and for the kids to have to be masked when the kids are the least vulnerable and the most susceptible to the psychological/emotional damage is a crime. It should be actionable, but realistically it's not.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: I have to make one last statistical point. If you had Omicron and you -- and got well, because everyone got well but just about who -- if you are vaccinated, double vaccinated and boosted and you got Omicron that was a nonevent in your life, other than an inconvenience, and maybe you couldn't compete in the Olympics. That's what changed. A year ago --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: In your life!

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: A year ago -- a year ago, no one knew where this was going.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I did.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: They were just trying. Give them the benefit of the doubt. They were just trying to make the best of a horrible situation.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Well, and we have vaccines.

utterances.speaker: PIRRO
utterances.sentences: The benefit of the doubt when they wouldn't even tell us where it came from or that they were funding --

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: They didn't know!

utterances.speaker: PIRRO
utterances.sentences: -- gain of function. They were funding gain of function when we were trying to figure it out when China wouldn't help us out. Look, this has been political --

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: We'll see what history says about that, I don't know.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Here's the deal.

utterances.speaker: PIRRO
utterances.sentences: I know.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Dana?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Which one of you is going to nominate me for the Nobel Prize? Because who said on this show, February 1st was going to start.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: I mailed it -- I mailed it yesterday.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: And look at this. It is -- it has unfolded like a glorious production, a giant dream!

utterances.speaker: PIRRO
utterances.sentences: Like who knows?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I don't even think I belong on television anymore.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: We're already given you the MVP over Tom Brady from your high school.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: All right.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: Enough.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Up next, a squad member claims defunding the police is not the problem, even during a crime wave.

utterances.speaker: PIRRO
utterances.sentences: Well, you know, when she was asked that question, not the specific one, but when she was asked, you know, about the hypocrisy of it all, and I'm so tired of using that word, I want to like put it away for the rest of the year. When she was asked, you spent over $300,000 for your own security, her response there was, you want to see me dead? Is that what you want? You want to see me dead?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Her life is more important --

utterances.speaker: PIRRO
utterances.sentences: OK.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: -- than everyone else.

utterances.speaker: PIRRO
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: That's what people don't understand.

utterances.speaker: PIRRO
utterances.sentences: Right. Right. So, you have to say to yourself, what is going on here? What is going on that we are masking our kids when we know that they are emotionally suffering as a result of it? What is going on that the mom- and-pop stores are being shut down and the big box stores are being saved? You know, like what is going on when you've got truckers all over the world now? You've got Canada, you've got the United States, France, other countries. People are saying we want to be able to work, we want to be able to live our lives in freedom, and we want to law and order. And these people who brought in this social justice nonsense have ruined it. The truth is we knew how to fight law and order. We knew it a long time ago. And now, they want to just eliminate it and talk about defunding police while other people died. Last point. I'd like to know, in the inner city, in New York City, and any other city, how many -- how many people of color have died as a result of taking out street crime units or anti-crime units? You know, what is the impact on real people as opposed to these criminals running around, or guys with 16 priors for robbery, assault, burglary? It takes a baseball bat, whines himself up and beats an Asian woman across the head from behind, she's got a fractured skull unconscious in several places. Who knows if she'll lived? He has been charged with 16 other crimes. Look at him right there whining up.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Yes. And Greg, he went out after bashing her skull in and grabbed a slice of pizza.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: What is with this attack on Asians? I mean, we -- the ones --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: -- we, the media used to talk about this when they thought they had the appropriate narrative that they like, and then all of a sudden, the races change. You can't -- no one brings it up, but it is overwhelming how many times you hear about Asian, elderly Asian, Asian women, it's really --

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: And a black perpetrator.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: And a black -- yes, yes. I mean, it's like, it's insane! Anyway, I'm mad at the New York Post for not using the correct headline which would have been the purloiner of the sirloiner (Ph). This has got really --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: I got to see the guy without the mask, that might have been you, by the way.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: It might have been me.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: I saw you ribs the other day.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Look, you know who is really upset about this? The day after Mayor Adams tries to push veganism.

utterances.speaker: PIRRO
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: What happens? Here's the guy that's stealing a stock of steak -- I'm talking about a slap in the face with a T-bone. I mean, it's like, it's like, why don't you steal plant-based foods? Why don't you do that? Meanwhile, I mean, and the other thing, too, is Tom Cotton is investigating this arson sentence for this guy -- set fire to a pawn shop, killed the person.

utterances.speaker: PIRRO
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Got a lenient sentence. A sentence cut in half because it happened during the George Floyd riots. So, what's the lesson? Hey, if you want a better chance of getting away with a crime like murder maybe, do it in a media or Democrat approved insurrection, but if you try anything like in a riot in D.C. on January 6th, if you happen to walk in, you are going to get five years.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: And this D.A., Bragg, what's going on with him? Did he walk it back, is he scared?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Which -- you mean, his memo?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Yes, this crazy guy, this D.A. here.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Yes, I think that he -- I think that he has realized that it's not going to fly. You said something the first day we talked about him. You said New York will never stand for that.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: No, we won't.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: And I remember -- I'm fairly new to New York, right, I've only lived -- I've lived here for 10 years, but it feels like I'm new. But when you said that, I thought, OK, I can see that where people are like no, we're not going to deal with this in this way. And Greg pointed out to me in the green room that Al Sharpton is now complaining about the crime and saying --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: My God.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: -- and asking the mayor to do something.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Al Sharpton, Bill Maher, THE FIVE, we are in agreement on everything.

utterances.speaker: PIRRO
utterances.sentences: Really?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: So, I'd say one thing about Cori Bush.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: So, it's Al Sharpton --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: -- and Bill Maher and THE FIVE, we're all in agreement on everything.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: yes.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: And why Al Sharpton is mad? Why? Because he -- it is Duane Reade, they lock up the toothpaste.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Wait, what? That's why. You know, he has a point.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: He has a point.

utterances.speaker: PIRRO
utterances.sentences: He said that -- he said that --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Everything is locked up! Have you gone to buy toiletries recently?

utterances.speaker: PIRRO
utterances.sentences: Not in --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Deodorants.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: You have to keep something and then you have to say, you know, can someone help me in the blank aisle?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: That's why you just order from Amazon.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: Al Sharpton is one of the smartest people in public life, I tell you. I've known him forever. He is.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Geraldo?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: He is.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: I have to cut you off.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: I think defund the police is the gift the Democrats are giving the Republicans; they won't stop giving. I mean, it is absolutely preposterous.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: It is why they almost lost Congress the last time around. It's why they are going to lose Congress this time around --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: This time.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: -- if they can focus from -- Republicans can stay focused. You know, I really think that what we need, we need more cops, we need more minority cops, we need better paid cops. We need stop question and frisk back. We need to hold store owners like Trader Joe's responsible when they intentionally allow a thief to walk out and they do nothing to stop it. That only perpetuates this misery and adds to this epidemic.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: There are lawsuits, Geraldo.

utterances.speaker: PIRRO
utterances.sentences: But they are afraid of being sued.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: But they should get sued by the municipality --

utterances.speaker: PIRRO
utterances.sentences: I agree. I agree.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: -- for encouraging and creating a climate of lawlessness.

utterances.speaker: PIRRO
utterances.sentences: I like that.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Now everybody sues everybody.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Did you want to say one other thing?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Well, I just want to say about Cori Bush real quick. The reason that the Democrats are having to try to distance themselves from her is because Speaker Pelosi gave her so much clout --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: -- in the beginning. Remember when she stayed the night on the capitol steps, and she wanted the illegal eviction moratorium to be extended? And Biden said we can't, and everybody knew that that would be the end result and they still allowed her to do that. That's why she has the platform that she has. They gave her it.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: All right.

utterances.speaker: PIRRO
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Trader Joe's, we'll be there in a little bit.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Not plant-based. We're coming for the meat. Up next, liberal cities losing control. Why a homeless person could end up being your next roommate.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: I'm ready. Right next to Jesse Jr.'s crib.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: Right next to --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: We'll make a little comfortable area.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: And with a spare door, right?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Hide the baseball bat.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: You know, maybe overnights that can work. You know, sometimes, you don't feel like waking up at 2 a.m. The government has quit.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: They've just said, you know what, we can't do this anymore.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: You take them.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Exactly.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: I've never seen this happen before. Well, they did it with the border. So, they're now doing it with homeless people. And now they're also, I think are they buying crack pipes? Was that a real story?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: They are sending crack pipes.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Smoking kits is what's called.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Right. And there is a crack pipe in the kit?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Right. So, it's like here is your crack pipe, take the homeless, the border is open. We are just going to fiddle around with racism for the next three years. This is what we are dealing with, Geraldo! I mean, no one would ever do it, no woman would ever do it. No family would ever do it. It would probably be some like mangy single due just out of college really hungry for some cash. But that's a roll of the dice.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: but there are some mangy dudes right out of college looking for a couple of bucks.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: All in San Francisco.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: All in -- there and elsewhere.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Yes, but I don't know. I don't think it's worth the risk, Geraldo, and you know it better than anybody.

utterances.speaker: PIRRO
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: Remember when Ed Koch was mayor?

utterances.speaker: PIRRO
utterances.sentences: Sure.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: We had the liberal, you know, ethos to be compassionate. Ed Koch stunned New York when he said -- the mayor of New York said, pass them by, give them nothing.

utterances.speaker: PIRRO
utterances.sentences: The homelessness.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: Because when you give them something, they use it to buy drugs or alcohol.

utterances.speaker: PIRRO
utterances.sentences: Homeless.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: And it really started a hardening of New Yorkers, you know, establishment New Yorkers towards the homeless. And I think it made the problem less severe for a time.

utterances.speaker: PIRRO
utterances.sentences: Well, you know, I looked it up today. Because I couldn't -- I couldn't figure out who is responsible for this. First of all, as a matter of fact, California has the most homeless people in the country.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: The best climate, too.

utterances.speaker: PIRRO
utterances.sentences: And the best climate. Maybe that's why they go there.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: PIRRO
utterances.sentences: Maybe they don't want -- OK, I'm not going to go there. There is an agency in the federal government, and it's called the United States Interagency Council on Homelessness. It's the only agency at a federal level whose sole responsibility it is to end homelessness, and it works with 19 other federal agencies. They have money, they say the number one cause of homelessness is the lack of affordable housing. We've got section eight. We've got all that stuff. That's what I read. I'm looking it up.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes, it's wrong, but, yes.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: I agree.

utterances.speaker: PIRRO
utterances.sentences: OK, let's say it's wrong. I don't know what the reason.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I do.

utterances.speaker: PIRRO
utterances.sentences: But what I do know is this.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: Mental illness and nutrition.

utterances.speaker: PIRRO
utterances.sentences: OK, mental illness, that's fine. Here's my point. Would I let them of my house? Not a chance! Not a chance. Because most of the people that we are seeing right now who are on the street, who are taking bats to people - - how many times have you heard they are homeless? They're homeless. They've got a mental health illness. They've got a mental health problem. We have to fix the mental health problem.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: And maybe if you are filling a baseball team, but you know, not to sleep over, seriously. But you hear the thing in The Times, I read that paper now, Dana?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Got it. They had a report, the guy that runs the biggest homeless shelter in New York City, just got arrested for taking $300,000 in kickbacks.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: And his name is Rivera.

utterances.speaker: PIRRO
utterances.sentences: Kickbacks?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Unrelated.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: No relation. Mayor Adams did say something very interesting today, Dana. He said, the problem -- much of the problem lies in, as I mentioned with the judge, lack of facilities for the mentally ill. He wants to immediately create many more beds for the acute -- you know, the problem is they get off their meds. But he wants to create, you know, not institutions, but facilities for the medically ill.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Well, look, the previous mayor gave his wife $1 billion to spend on this very issue. And then they had to come out with a report a year and a half ago that said, whoops, we have no idea how that money was spent. So, if we talk about compassion, none of this is compassion. Like letting people sit there in their own filth is not compassionate in any way. And I do think that, you know, the government giving up and saying, could you guys just take these people in because that'd be really helpful, what's the next step? You know, I do think that the question about how many people we are allowing into this country illegally is that question. Like, will you take more people in? No. At some point, there has to be some sort of tough love. And I know Greg has a lot to say and I'm going to leave it there.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: Are you into tough love today?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Well, in many, many ways, Geraldo, I am. This would make sense, right? If you were talking about a child who lost their family in a fire, with somebody who is temporary without a roof.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: But those usually exist.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: They're -- you can count them on your hands.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Hurricane victims.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Metaphorically giant hand. That's not the issue. We've all seen the homeless situation. We've seen it up close. We don't need to pretend there are two million children down on their luck. These are not children, right? These are men, many are criminal, many are mentally ill, many are drug addicts. That's a fact that you don't hear in these commission on homelessness, right? They paint it as just the little teary-eyed people that are down on their luck. No, they're not. These are not characteristics for a sound roommate unless Gavin Newsom takes four of them into one of his mansions, I do not believe this will ever happen. You brought up the idea of -- it's all about affordable housing. If you Google stuff on homelessness, that's the number one hit. It's about affordable housing. That is a lie. It has no effect on the transient population. If you do not contribute to society through work, the only affordable housing has to be free. It doesn't matter if it's $300 a month or $200, they're not going to pay. The money for most homeless goes to drugs and alcohol. I know that's politically incorrect to say but it's an unspeakable truth. Geraldo brought up the idea that California has the most because of the climate. That's what you call a choice, right? It's preferable. So, it's -- many people prefer to be homeless, no rent, no food to buy no bills, find a shelter, free meals, get drugs, sustainable lifestyle. And you know why it's sustainable or you know the proof that it's sustainable? It's not shrinking. It's growing.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: It's growing.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: It's growing because it's possible. The idea that it's not enough affordable housing, that is true for people who are working, who are -- who have low-income people. Yes, but they're not the homeless people. Do not be tricked to do this. Because that is why we're not fixing --

utterances.speaker: PIRRO
utterances.sentences: So you think all the homeless, they just don't want anywhere to live.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I think --

utterances.speaker: PIRRO
utterances.sentences: So, why the -- who are they taking in? We've read about these this article. This woman said, this woman said I took a homeless person.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Look at the numbers. There's -- you can -- again, you could count them. It's so few that they can get. They can't match them.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: The other thing that Ed Koch did during his administration was to give bus tickets to anywhere they wanted to go -- anywhere you want to go. But then they had to go. The cop would take them to the Port Authority. They get on the bus for wherever. Then the wherever started saying, we don't want you either. Straight ahead, have woke liberal policies and soaring costs killed college as we know it?

utterances.speaker: PIRRO
utterances.sentences: More proof that college may not be worth it thanks to the high -- the sky-high cost of tuition that is set to get even higher and campuses becoming a breeding ground for radical left-wing indoctrination. 55 percent of high schoolers say they don't think college is even needed for a successful career. And they're right. All right, so what we've got are a lot of kids saying now, Dana, that they don't need to go to college, that you know, they're going to do whatever they want in terms of what their passion is. They don't feel that obligation. What do you think that is?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Well, I think some of them want -- really focus and do a good job in the -- even in our public school system and K through 12, because you can get a good education if you focus. You don't have to go to a fancy school where there's like lots of partying and socializing. Like, that is fun. Don't get me wrong.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: You were crazy back then.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Unbelievable the things that I got up to, the sporting events and things like that. But you pay a prize for it later, right? There's a wonderful book called The Defining Decade by Dr. Meg Jay. She's out of UVA. And it's about how you have to invest in yourself in your 20s, so that you can have a better rest of your life. I highly recommend it to anybody, especially graduates if you have them in your life right now. Because if you go to college, and you end up in debt, and then you come out of it, and you're trying to figure out a way to get out of that cycle, it's really bad. I do think that college can be very good and rewarding for people. But there are -- there comes a limit, all of that that I just mentioned. Plus, when you go into the classroom, if it's all just going to be about woke identity politics, you're not going to learn anything.

utterances.speaker: PIRRO
utterances.sentences: Well, you know, Greg, even in terms of what Dana is saying, there are 10 universities that are absolutely considered non free speech universities from Stanford to the University of -- what is it -- North Carolina at Chapel Hill? And, you know, I think they even have Georgetown in there.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PIRRO
utterances.sentences: It's pretty amazing.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Georgetown sucks. That's -- a lot of people don't realize that but --

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: How nice of you to mention that.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Would -- they're weirdos that go to Georgetown. What students are experiencing is reverse knowledge. They're going to college and they exited dumber. And why would you -- and as college costs go up, the quality of education just gets worse. It has to change and that parents have to be more educated about these colleges, figure out which ones are actually great. They're not expensive. But the real cause of all of our problems happens before college. By the time someone is 17, they're either on a good track or they're in a hole. And we see that the state of the public high schools were kind of like building a second floor on a house where there is no first floor when we're talking about college. The first floor, we don't even have that anymore. Our public high schools are terrible. We got to get these -- we got to get these kids before they get to college.

utterances.speaker: PIRRO
utterances.sentences: Yes. And you know, Geraldo, I mean, of the kids who don't really have a plan, half of those kids postgraduate after high school don't even know what their options are, which in itself suggests that they're not even aware of some of the skilled trades and that maybe they're not getting taught things that some of these kids might want to work at.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: I think that is absolutely true. They -- we denigrate the skilled trades. I had an old bronze piece I had brought home from Africa that was all broken up. And these guys, these welders came, they're making 100 grand a year.

utterances.speaker: PIRRO
utterances.sentences: Yes. Good for them.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: They kids. I mean, it's great. The problem is student loans.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Are you looting African entrepreneurs?

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: Student loans -- I paid full retail.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: OK.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: Student loans are what's destroying --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: -- many men. I was famous for three years before I paid off my student loan. People get the money, kids get the money. They have no economic education. They have no financial education.

utterances.speaker: PIRRO
utterances.sentences: Right. They don't know the reality.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: So, they get the money, they spend the money, they have the party, they have nice apartment.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: They major in sociology.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: And they -- a trade that has absolutely no market value. And they graduate $200,000 in debt. So if you're -- if you get an education degree and you're 200,000 debt, you'll never pay it off. You'll never -- you're better off becoming something where you don't have to borrow that money.

utterances.speaker: PIRRO
utterances.sentences: Well --

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: You know, different strokes for different folks.

utterances.speaker: PIRRO
utterances.sentences: OK, Jesse, you can wrap it up. I mean, AOC wants to eliminate student debt.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Her student debt. That's what she wants to get rid of. You guys are sounding a little negative, you know. I don't like that. You guys loved college. All of you loved college.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I hate it.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Greg, I loved college and you all go back to college. And your kids, you want your kids to go to college.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Yes, I do. it's true.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: I want my kids and they will go to college. And the best part about college is the networking you get. You meet people that are also maybe from successful families that can afford to send you to college. And then when you get out of college --

utterances.speaker: PIRRO
utterances.sentences: Isn't that like old --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: -- you get -- you have relationships and then your life kind of ticked off.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: How many people you still talk to from college?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes, I don't --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: I talk to no one from college.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: Where did you go to college?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: But people tell me that's really important.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Only to Georgetown.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: I heard you're very unpopular.

utterances.speaker: PIRRO
utterances.sentences: All right, ahead, act up on a flight and you could end up on a list reserved for terrorists.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Throw a fit on your next flight and you could wind up in the same category as Bin Laden. Delta CEO urged the Biden administration to create a national no-fly list for unruly passengers. And Transportation Secretary Pete Buttigieg says they could be on board with the idea. He's dead that guy.

utterances.speaker: PETE BUTTIGIEG, SECRETARY OF TRANSPORTATION
utterances.sentences: I think we need to take a look at it. This is happening at an unacceptable rate. Anything besides zero is an unacceptable rate. If you are on board an aircraft you need to be -- I can't believe we've even have to say this. But you need to listen to what flight crews say and you need to act in a way that is safe.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Bin Laden was on a no fly list. That's award-winning writing. OK, Judge --

utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.sentences: Yes. Well, look, I think that this new rule, honestly, is a good rule. I do, OK, because I've been flying --

utterances.sentences: Damn you.

utterances.sentences: I've been flying since the pandemic allowed us to fly, right? And there's crazy people out there. They're in the airports and they're on the airplane. And people are edgy, and they want to fight. And they shouldn't be allowed on planes because planes are very tight -- they're tight quarters. I mean, other people get involved, other people get hit. You've got flight attendants, you've got the crew, you've got 80-year-olds in there, and you've got nut jobs. And they're not even serving alcohol on the plane.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I know.

utterances.speaker: PIRRO
utterances.sentences: So, wait until they do that.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Geraldo, you fly private so this doesn't concern you. But don't you think that the people that flip out on planes generally don't fly that often anyway. They're usually not --

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: Well, I don't know about that, but I think they should be gaffer- taped by the crews to their chairs. I'd love to volunteer to do that. I was on a no-fly list.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Oh, really.

utterances.speaker: PIRRO
utterances.sentences: You were?

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: And we could never find out what it was for. It lasted for months. And we were pounding Washington. I came to the conclusion because I had a mustache and there was the war on drugs going on at the time. But I agree that there's some places you cannot mess, you cannot mess around. And in an airplane, you don't mess around. That's my safety, my kids safety, my wife safety. You're acting up. Who knows what could happen? Forget about it. No fly. Plus, diamond, unique like you in Delta, so we deserve --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Geraldo, I agree with you. I agree with you. You can't slow me down. I have places to go. And if you're going to cause a ruckus, and then do it again a month later, put them on a list. You get kicked out of casinos if you misbehave.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: That's true.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: You know, you get your license revoked if you drive drunk too many times. Strip these guys have their freedom. Put them on the ground. Make them walk. Make them take a train, a bus. If you're going to screw around 10,000 feet up in the air, forget about it. You're done.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: And you know what? It's probably mostly Democrats.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Thank you. Thank you for finally getting to the interesting part. Dana, why should Democrats be allowed to fly? Liberals --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS

utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PERINO

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: That is so true. Again, you pierce through the miasma.

utterances.speaker: PIRRO
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: So, find the truth.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: What about that lady that made the plane turn around 500 mile en route to England from Miami?

utterances.sentences: Oh, I would have been furious.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Put her to Gitmo.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: Imagine if you were on that plane.

utterances.speaker: PIRRO
utterances.sentences: Furious.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: On that plane and your whole vacation screwed up. You get a connecting flight from London or someplace else.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Oh, yes, you're right.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: Jail.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I agree. "ONE MORE THING" up next.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: It's time now for "ONE MORE THING." Jesse.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS

utterances.sentences: Oh, that's terrible.

utterances.sentences: Don't swear, Dana.

utterances.sentences: All right, so the guy takes off a shoe and just starts beating this poor lizard in the face.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Poor lizard.

utterances.sentences: Well, I mean, Dana, these are God's great creatures. I mean, come on. What are you going to do? Lizard is going to lizard. He doesn't know anything.

utterances.sentences: You are sympathetic to the alligator.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: All across.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: OK, Geraldo.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: OK, time for Geraldo's Geraldo news with Geraldo news from the vault. News from the vault. It's a sad news, actually. Seriously, a sad news. New York City's first Latina broadcaster Gloria Rojas passed away last week. Gloria made her debut 1968. She was a school teacher until she became a broadcaster. She recruited me. I was a street lawyer at the time to a fellowship program that she had attended also at Columbia University's Graduate School of Journalism. So, she was the first Latina on TV and I was the first Latino as the article in The New York Times in 1971 makes clear. So, I was very proud of that association. I always -- I never would have been a broadcaster but for Gloria.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: There he is.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: And I -- condolences to her family and she was a wonderful person. That's Melba Tolliver. Wonderful -- also wonderful.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: I love those. I love local news, indeed. All right, we'll switch gears a little bit because I have these picture of these -- you know, we all -- we all want to get outside. utterances.sentences: I saw his gum.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.sentences: A lot of wind. Clear the cobwebs out of those pups. All right, Judge, what do you have?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Wow.

utterances.sentences: And as always, the cop gets the criminal.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Wow.

utterances.speaker: PIRRO
utterances.sentences: The feline is back in the car. And I've got to tell you --

utterances.speaker: PIRRO
utterances.sentences: All right. That shows you how hard it is for cops to do their job. But they never -- they never faint. They never resist doing their job.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: It's pretty good. What do you have for us?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Well, tonight, on my show, it's really great. I have Emily Compagno. You've ever heard of her?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: No.

utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.sentences: Yes. They're all paying the price, Judge.

utterances.sentences: Pink -- there you go.

utterances.sentences: Oh, that's even better.

utterances.sentences: You have anything else you would like to promote, Judge?

utterances.sentences: That was at the zoo, by the way.

utterances.speaker: DANA PERINO, FOX NEWS HOST
utterances.utterance: Hello, everyone. I'm Dana Perino along with Judge Jeanine Pirro, Geraldo Rivera, Jesse Watters, and Greg Gutfeld.
